bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose A. Presno, January 6, 1954

div1.p: Hench tries to arrange a meeting with Presno to discuss microfilming Finlay's daybooks.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose A. Presno, January 6, 1954
div1.opener:
January 6, 1954
Dr. Jose A. Presno, President
Academy of Sciences
Cuba 460
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Presno:
div1.p:
I have had the pleasure of meeting you on several occasions. The last
time was when I had the great honor to receive the Finlay Medal at the
Academy of Sciences in Havana in January, 1952.

You may remember also my great interest in the work of Doctor Finlay and
of the members of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Commission. For ten years
I have been collecting data on the conquest of yellow fever and it is my
great desire to tell the Americans in my book as much as I can about
Doctor Finlay for my countrymen do not know enough about him.

About three years age when I was in Havana, Dr. Pedro Nogueira called my
attention to the eight or nine day-books or diaries of Doctor Finlay de-
posited in the library of the Academy of Sciences. After studying these
with great eagerness I recognize how tremendously important they were for
anyone trying to write something on the life of Doctor Finlay. I discussed
with you the possibility of having microfilms made of every page of these
eight or nine volumes but at that time there was in Havana no company
able to make such microfilms. You graciously considered the possibility
of permitting me to take these diaries personally to the Surgeon General's
Library so that they might have microfilms made, not only for the Surgeon
General's Library but an extra copy for the Academy of Sciences in case
anything should happen to the original; but at the last moment the matter
was postponed.

On my return from Cuba at that time, I told the Surgeon General of the U. S.
Army of these very important volumes and he too expressed a hope that a
microfilm could be made sometime and deposited in the Library of the
Surgeon General.

On my visit to Havana in January 1952, I spoke to you again of this matter
and again you were quite willing for it to be done if it could be done
under the proper auspices and with safeguards for the volumes. Recently
the Surgeon General learned that I was to return to Havana and has, I
believe, written to you making an official request in this matter. I have
just heard from him and he has asked me to try to meet you and discuss the
matter with you when I come to Havana in about three weeks, January 26 - 29.

It is my understanding from the Surgeon General that if they were permitted
to have a microfilm of these volumes, they would be delighted to have a
copy made for the Library of the Academy of Sciences. The Surgeon General

- 2 -
January 6, 1954
indicates to me that the microfilming could probably be done least
expensively in the Library of the Surgeon General in Washington. There-
fore, if you and the Librarian of the Academy would be willing to trust
the volumes to me, I could take them to Washington and have them micro-
filmed and then they could be taken by an agent of the Surgeon General
to the Cuban Embassy and returned by diplomatic pouch. However we want
to do whatever seems best and if it seems better to have them micro-
filmed in Cuba, and this could be done at a reasonable price, that would
be entirely satisfactory. I am sure you understand the tremendous im-
portance of Doctor Finlay's day books to anyone who wants to study the
conquest of yellow fever. Unfortunately, for an occasional visitor like
me who can stay only a few days in Havana, the diaries are several in
number and are written variously in Spanish, sometimes in German or English,
so that it has been impossible for me to study them unless a copy were
made available.

The Surgeon General having asked me to act as an agent in the matter,
permit me to request an appointment with you perhaps for sometime Wed-
nesday, January 27, or any day that week. I shall contact your office
through the help of my friend, Dr. Pedro Nogueira.

I am coming to Havana in the interests of F.I.M. and Mrs. Hench and I
will be the guests of our old friends, Senorits Maria Teresa Rojas and
Senorita Lidia Cabrera at the Finca San Jose, Calle Real, Marianao,
the old site of Camp Lazear.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
